awd_titl_txt: TWC: Small: Provably Enforcing Practical Multi-Layer Policies in Today's Extensible Software Platforms
awd_abstract_narration:
A defining characteristic of modern personal computing is the trend towards extensible platforms (e.g., smartphones and tablets) that run a large number of specialized applications, many of uncertain quality or provenance. The common security mechanisms available on these platforms are application isolation and permission systems.  Unfortunately, it has been repeatedly shown that these mechanisms fail to prevent a range of misbehaviors, including privilege-escalation attacks and information-flow leakage.  Researchers have proposed information-flow protections for these platforms. However, such mechanisms have rarely been adopted in practice, partly due to the level of abstraction at which they allow policies to be specified.

We develop a formal, case-study-driven approach that will leverage advances in information-flow research to develop new policy-specification languages and enforcement mechanisms for today's extensible environments.  First, we develop appropriate policy-specification languages that allow policies to be specified at an intermediate level of abstraction.  Policy specification will be easy enough to understand and formulate to be accessible to most developers, yet sufficiently expressive to support rich policies.  Second, we develop hybrid enforcement mechanisms to support policy that is specified at levels of abstraction that do not neatly overlap isolation boundaries provided by the platform.  Third, the correctness of the mechanisms will be supported by formal models and proofs.  To remain grounded and ensure practical relevance, we focus our work on two application domains: the Android operating system, and, secondarily, the Chromium web browser.

por.por_cntn:
A defining characteristic of modern personal computing is the trend towards extensible platforms (e.g., smartphones and tablets) that run many specialized applications, often of uncertain quality or provenance. This project used information flow control (IFC)---an approach for protecting sensitive data from being leaked and sensitive program components from tampering---to develop mechanisms to analyze and secure web browsers and other platforms.

 

This project developed a formal model for coarse-grained taint-tracking: a practical runtime mechanism for enforcing information flow control on extensible platforms. Such an enforcement mechanism only checks security policies when messages are passed between components (e.g., different Android applications), which is more efficient that checking policies at every instruction. This model naturally captures key features of extensible platforms (including web applications, browser extensions, and Android apps) by describing how event handlers and shared storage interoperate, which is the core of these systems. Using this model, we are able to prove the design of our enforcement mechanism secure. This project also developed a compositional language for studying timing-sensitive information flow security. The meta-theory of this language guarantees that the composed system does not leak information through timing channels if its subcomponents do not. Using this language, we were able to pinpoint problematic components that leak timing information in an earlier design of an information flow control-enabled browser.

 

This project also developed two program analysis tools to identify information leaks in Android applications. The first tool implements a light-weight algorithm that identifies potential information leaks within a set of applications, preventing leaks that might exist only when two applications interact. The second tool detects subtle information flows within applications that may accidentally make an untrusted component of an application privy to sensitive data..

 

In the space of emerging application domains, this project conducted one of the first systematic analysis of security and privacy issues in IFTTT, a service that allows anyone to write simple programs that connect their Internet-of-Things devices with online services. The analysis showed that many of the “programs” end-users use to move information between their web services (like social network and online file storage) and IoT devices may leak private data and cause people’s IoT devices and online accounts to be manipulated in unexpected and potentially harmful ways.

 

The research advances enabled by this project raise awareness of and improve the security of platforms that users interact with every day. The project provided training for several undergraduates and graduate students, including several from underrepresented groups, and post-doctoral researchers. Two of the PhD students participated in this projects have graduated and taken positions in academic institutions.
